The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-288-3136. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

Course and Title: BIOL 025: Forensic Biology
3.0 Units
Lecture Hours: 3.0 Lab Hours: 0.0 Advisory Basic Skills: R/W 3; Math 3 Prerequisite: None Corequisite: None Recommended Preparation: Course Description: This course is a general education science lecture course intended for those who have a general interest in the application of science to forensic science. Scientific method, mathematical computations, and fundamental principles of physics, chemistry and biology will be applied to various forms of evidence to derive information about a crime scene. items.item_details:
The accreditation standards ask that colleges periodically reaffirm their institutional mission statements.  Toward this end, the college held a campus wide retreat on October 23, 2009 as the first step in updating our strategic plan.  Initially the discussion focused on the district’s values of opportunity equity and social justice. This provided a framework for revisiting the college’s mission.  Based on input from the retreat, a subcommittee representing campus constituency groups met several times to further refine a proposed mission statement.  At the January 2010 PDD, the campus community had an opportunity to vote on two proposed statements.  The selected mission statement was then sent to the College Council where constituency representatives were given an additional opportunity to garner feedback from their constituencies. On April 26, 2010 the College Council adopted the College’s Mission Statement.
The Mission Statement defines the institution’s broad educational purposes, its intended population, and its commitment to achieving student learning.
Mission Statement
With equity, opportunity and social justice as our guiding principles, Evergreen Valley College’s mission is to empower and prepare students from diverse backgrounds to succeed academically and to be civically responsible global citizens.

This agreement is to request additional funds between the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District and California Community College System Office for the CalWORKs Program at San Jose City College.  The purpose of this agreement is to assist Former Foster Youth support services to our CalWork's participants' children ages 16-18.
The San Josè Evergreen Community College District (SJECCD)/San Josè City College (SJCC) has a demonstrated interest in proactively working with and serving foster youth to ensure that they have a supportive and nurturing environment as a foundation on which to build successful emancipation.
	The San Josè City College Community College Pathways program will be designed to enhance the personal, academic, and career outcomes for former foster youth by integrating comprehensive student support services with basic skills instruction that further develops reading, writing, math and critical thinking skills.

items.item_details:
For many years, the daily parking fee has remained at $2. Students typically choose to pay the semester rate, which is capped at $40 by state regulations. However, visitors and students who only attend occasionally must pay the daily parking fee or risk being issued a citation for a parking violation. 
	 
The current budget challenge facing the District is so significant that every means must be evaluated to assist in maintaining programs and services. A recommendation was brought to the Board of Trustees to raise the daily parking fee to $3/day in December 2008, as well as in May 2009.  The District Budget Committee also recommended the daily parking fee increase at their March 4, 2010 meeting.
	 
In the Board’s Study Session on the budget conducted in February 2010, a presentation was made indicating that the daily parking fee is one of the only fees under the control of the Board of Trustees. Almost all other fees are set by the State or are structured to give the local board minimal choices, such as in setting tuition for non-resident students. 
	 
The revenue collected in daily passes in FY2008/09 was approximately $180,000.  An increase from $2 to $3 would yield approximately $90,000 in additional revenue on an annual basis.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve an increase in the daily parking fee rate from $2 to $3 effective June 1, 2010
